Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Scaling Cluster Computing Fabrics with Optical Networking
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result from developing technology to enable enterprise, cloud, academic, and government network operators to cost-effectively scale computer clusters to support the growing demands on these systems. Computer clusters underpin an increasingly broad range of services that businesses, researchers, and society have come to rely on, from machine learning systems to online social media platforms. Companies increasingly use computer clusters to gain a competitive advantage and accelerate product development. Today's networking technologies improve in performance by a factor of two every two years, but the demand placed on cluster computing systems is growing more than twice that fast in some market segments. The technology developed through this project is well-positioned to exceed the cost and performance scaling limitations of current networking technology, enabling business and scientific end-users to find solutions to more complex problems more quickly.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project demonstrates the feasibility of a network interconnect for computer clusters that routes traffic through transparent optical switches. Optical switches remove communication bottlenecks in the network fabric but require fundamental changes in how distributed applications communicate information across the network compared to present-day technologies. The commercial success of the technology depends on its ability to accelerate the execution of common distributed applications while providing the interoperability, reliability, and manageability expected by network operators. This project aims to demonstrate a 2x improvement in the execution speed of network-bound applications compared to today's technologies. The proposed research to reach this goal includes developing and optimizing the software stack necessary to interface commodity applications with the fabric, quantifying the performance of those applications subject to the constraints imposed by optical switching, and optimizing the optical switch design to maximize application performance at a system level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cluster computing systems connect many individual computers using a network, allowing them to work together to solve large business and research problems as well as deliver today's myriad consumer-facing web and mobile applications. inFocus Networks is developing an optical networking technology called Opera to improve the performance and economics of these cluster computing systems. Today's cluster networks use electronic network switches, but optical network switches enable lower cost and improved scalability. However, using them requires fundamental changes in how data traffic is communicated across the network. Opera is a hardware and software system that addresses this challenge while delivering the benefits of optical switching.

This Phase I project initially focused on demonstrating Opera's potential to improve the performance-per-dollar of data center and high-performance computing networks for real applications. Previous simulations were promising, but an application-level demonstration was necessary to make concrete claims about performance. A primary research challenge was to enable software applications originally designed to communicate using today's conventional networks to communicate efficiently using Opera. This required the design and implementation of an application interface for Opera, which was used to show that an important class of distributed applications can run with no loss in communication efficiency. Paired with a detailed analysis of Opera's practical implementation constraints and overall cost savings, this enabled a doubling in performance-per-dollar for application-specific data center and high-performance computing networks, potentially saving hundreds of millions of dollars for large cluster deployments, and meeting the original project goal.

While the proposed technological development of Opera was successful, Phase I commercialization efforts indicated the timeframe for commercial adoption in the data center and high-performance computing markets was farther away than originally thought. Through those commercialization efforts, however, inFocus Networks also discovered that its technology is well-suited to address challenges in distributed quantum computing, an emerging market with a more favorable competitive landscape and greater long-term potential.

Based on customers' requirements, inFocus Networks analyzed its technology's potential to enable scalable quantum computers. Quantum computers are anticipated to revolutionize fields including pharmaceutical development, finance, logistics, and information security by solving problems that are currently intractable using today's computers. However, current quantum computer prototypes are too small to solve practical problems. The results of this project show that inFocus Networks' optical switching technology can be a key enabler in building the first quantum computers large enough to solve real-world problems that have societal impact. The next steps for this project include building a quantum-optimized optical switch and working with quantum computer manufacturers to test and deploy the technology in the next generation of quantum computers.
